byline.contributor: Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting from Washington and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.

abstract: IRS discloses that organized criminals were able to gain access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people and to use information to claim some $50 million in fraudulent refunds; say criminals used Social Security numbers and other personal information that was obtained elsewhere to perpetrate the fraud; opens investigation and shuts down 'Get Transcript' application that was exploited.
lead_paragraph: Criminals gained access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people and used personal information to claim $50 million in fraudulent refunds, the agency said.

headline.print_headline: I.R.S. Breach Exposes Data of Taxpayers

snippet: Criminals gained access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people and used personal information to claim $50 million in fraudulent refunds, the agency said.
